questions.question: Training a neural network involves manually setting its internal weights and biases to pre-calculated correct values.
The text compares training a neural network to what real-world activity?
options: Building a complex machine
Solving a mathematical equation
Teaching a child to identify animals with flashcards
Navigating a maze

questions.question: Training a neural network means teaching it to make accurate predictions by adjusting its internal parameters, which are its _________ and _________.

sections.section: 3.2: The Core Concept: Learning by Error Correction

questions.question: The main goal of training is to find the optimal set of weights and biases so the network can accurately map inputs to outputs.
The core concept of training a neural network is best described as:
options: Randomly guessing until a correct answer is found.
Learning by correcting errors measured between predictions and actual outcomes.
Memorizing the entire training dataset perfectly.
Increasing the number of neurons until the network is large enough.

questions.question: Why are a network's weights and biases initialized with small, random numbers at the start of training?
options: To make the initial predictions as accurate as possible.
To ensure the network runs faster.
To break symmetry and allow the learning process to begin effectively.
To make the math easier for the first forward pass.

questions.question: The 'Forward Pass' is the step where the network's weights are updated based on the calculated error.
The network's prediction is compared to the true label using a _________ _________ to measure the size of the mistake.
What does a high 'loss' value signify?
options: The network is learning very quickly.
The network's prediction was very close to the correct answer.
The network has finished training.
The network's prediction was very inaccurate.

questions.question: Backpropagation is the process of sending the calculated error backward through the network to determine how to adjust the weights.
What two things does the 'gradient' calculated during backpropagation tell the network? (Select two)
options: The final prediction of the network.
The direction in which to adjust a weight to reduce loss.
The speed of the computer's processor.
How much a weight should be adjusted.
The number of layers in the network.

questions.question: What component is responsible for actually updating the weights using the gradients calculated by backpropagation?
options: The Loss Function
The Input Layer
An Optimizer (like Gradient Descent)
The Activation Function

questions.question: Setting a very high learning rate is always beneficial as it guarantees the network will learn faster and more accurately.
Which of the following statements about the Learning Rate are true according to the text? (Select all that apply)
options: A learning rate that is too high can cause the training to overshoot the optimal values.
The learning rate is automatically determined by the network.
A learning rate that is too low can make training very slow.
The learning rate's value increases after each epoch.

questions.question: One full pass through the entire training dataset is called one _________.
Which of the following correctly describes the sequence of events within a single iteration of the training loop?
options: Update Weights -> Forward Pass -> Calculate Loss -> Backpropagation
Calculate Loss -> Backpropagation -> Forward Pass -> Update Weights
Forward Pass -> Calculate Loss -> Backpropagation -> Update Weights
Backpropagation -> Update Weights -> Calculate Loss -> Forward Pass

questions.question: A neural network is typically fully trained after a single pass through the dataset (one epoch).
The text describes which component as the 'engine' that makes learning possible by efficiently calculating how to assign blame to each weight?
options: The Loss Function
Gradient Descent
The Learning Rate
Backpropagation

questions.question: The _________ _________ is described as the 'compass' that tells the network which way to go to improve.
What is the primary role of an optimizer like Gradient Descent?
options: To calculate the initial error of a prediction.
To randomly initialize the network's weights.
To change the weights in a way that minimizes the loss.
To feed data into the network's input layer.

questions.question: A network is considered 'trained' and ready for use on new data once the loss is acceptably low.
Which of the following are identified as critical components or concepts for effective training? (Select all that apply)
options: Backpropagation
The number of CPU cores
The Learning Rate
The Loss Function
The color of the flashcards
